Applies to

  • Java

What to Do

Centralize authentication controls.

Why

Implementing a single set of centralized authentication controls helps implement them correctly, use them correctly in the application, and manage them later on.

How

To centralize authentication controls:

  1. Identify application requirements. Consider the following aspects of authentication controls:

    • Authentication should be required for all private pages.
    • All password fields should be masked.
    • Accounts should be locked after multiple failed authentication attempts.
    • Authentication should be implemented on the server-side.
    • Authentication controls should be centralized.
    • Authentication controls should fail securely.
    • Strong authentication credentials (passwords) should be enforced.
    • Account management functions should be protected.
    • User credential (password) changing functions should be protected.
    • Re-authentication should be required for sensitive operations.
    • Authentication credentials (passwords) should expire.
    • Authentication events should be logged.
    • Passwords should be hashed and salted.
    • Authentication credentials (connection strings) for external resources should be protected.
    • Authentication with external services.

  2. Consider using authentication controls provided by the framework. Most frameworks offer authentication controls. Since there are many Java frameworks, we cannot examine them all in depth here. However, most frameworks should have authentication controls that are worth considering and may be sufficient for you application requirements. Even if authentication controls provided by the framework are used, it may be a good idea to write your own wrapper classes to centralize the authentication controls and to simplify using them.

  3. Define authentication control APIs. Make the exposed APIs simple to use for developers. Define authentication APIs to satisfy all application requirements. Include functionality to authenticate with external services.

  4. Implement and document authentication controls. It may be a good idea to write your own wrapper classes for authentication even if using controls provided by the framework or a third-party library. Implement and document authentication APIs to satisfy all application requirements.

  5. Use authentication controls in the application. Developers should use the centralized authentication controls whenever authentication is necessary.

Authentication Guidelines

  • Centralize Authentication Controls
  • Use Server-side Authentication
  • Make Sure Authentication Controls Fail Securely
  • Force Re-authentication When Executing Critical Functionality
  • Validate Usernames Before Processing Them
  • Lock Accounts After Consecutive Failed Login Attempts
  • Enforce Strong Passwords
  • Force Password Renewal
  • Mask All Password Fields
  • Verify the Application's Authenticity to the User
  • Place Logout Links on All Pages that Require Authentication
  • Do Not Leave Passwords in Memory
  • Limit Access to the Credential Store
  • Consider Using JAAS for Authentication
  • Consider Using Two Factor Authentication

Authentication Checklists

  • Authentication Controls Are Centralized
  • Server-side Authentication Is Used
  • Authentication Controls Fail Securely
  • Re-authentication Is Enforced When Executing Critical Functionality
  • Usernames Are Validated Before Use
  • Accounts Are Locked After Consecutive Failed Login Attempts
  • Strong Passwords Are Enforced
  • Password Renewal Is Enforced
  • All Password Fields Are Masked
  • The Application's Authenticity Is Verified to the User
  • All Pages that Use Authentication Have Logout Links
  • Passwords Are Not Left in Memory
  • Access to the Credential Store Is Limited
